newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST - Australian Sports News - April 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Australian Sports News - April 17.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

The Australian cricket team, which yesterday returned triumphant from its South African tour, is now preparing for the Ashes tour to England. England is not expected to pose a serious threat with commentators now ranking it below Australia, the West Indies and South Africa in terms of both Test and One Day international cricket. Page 14.

Sydney United will play the first game of the major semi-finals against the Brisbane Strikers team at Suncorp Stadium in two weeks. The decision by Soccer Australia has resolved a dispute about where the game should be played, but has upset Sydney United coach Branko Culina who would have preferred his team to play on home ground. Page 14.

The Australian swimming team, competing in the world short course titles in Gothenburg, Sweden, will be without its three world-class 1500 metre men's freestyle stars Kieren Perkins, Daniel Kowalski and Glen Housman. The three have dominated the event but 16-year-old Grant Hackett should perform well after beating Kowalski at the national championships in December 1996. Page 14.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Australian 1996 Olympic javelin silver medallist Louise McPaul will compete in the world championships in Athens in August against the advice of coach Peter Lawler, who is concerned she risks further physical damage and chronic injury and has advised her to take a year off competition. Page 45.

Australian swimmer Michael Klim claims to have perfected the submarine start to the 100m butterfly event favoured by main rival Russian Dennis Pankratov. The tactic enables a swimmer to swim the first lap and some of the second entirely underwater. Pankrtov is the current Olympic champion and world record holder, while Klim is ranked No 2. Page 46.

The Australian cricket team to tour England will be announced today. Speculation concerning the future of Australian captain Mark Taylor is rife, although he is largely expected to retain his position. Other team mates including Steve Waugh have expressd their support for him. Page 46.
THE AGE

Australian cyclist Cadel Evans has emerged as a leader in the mountain bike world cup following his win in the second round on New Zealand's Mt Victoria last weekend. His win was unexpected, as he defeated former world champion Gerome Chiotti, world cup champion Christoph Dupon and early leader Italian Dario Ceroni. Page B6.

Leading international soccer player Australian Paul Okon is expected to miss most of this year's World Cup series due to a severe inflammation of his pelvis. He has received medical advice saying he needs total rest once he completes the Italian Series A His exclusion is a blow to Australian national soccer coach Terry Venables. Page B6. --

The Australian Football League Tribunal yesterday disqualified Collingwood midfielder Scott Burns from competing in this Saturday's match against Carlton after he was suspended for two matches following his conviction for striking St Kilda's Stewart Loewelast Saturday. Page B8.
THE HERALD SUN

The Australian Football League has witnessed the debut of a striking new player Andrew Bomford of Essendon. Bomford has already played more reserve games than any other player (81) before making his senior debut. Page 83.

Melbourne Tigers basketball player Chika Emeagi is set to become one of the highlights of the Women's National Basketball League's new advertising campaign. Emeagi trained at the Australian Institute of Sport and where she won rookie of the year honours in 1995. Page 78.

Australian Football League team Adelaide Crows will face its main rivals and the newest team in the AFL competition, Port Adelaide, this Sunday. The hard fought game will be held in Adelaide, with sectarian passions among fans running high. Page 84.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

The Australian Surf Life Saving Championships main event, the Ironman competition, promises to be hard fought this year. The field will include six-time national champion Trevor Hendy and reigning world champion Nathan Meyer. Commentators say it is impossible to predict a winner. Page 77.

The Australian Rugby League is expected to announce the retirement of the New South Wales State of Origin coach Phil Gould today. He will be replaced by current ARL national coach Bob Fulton. Gould has been coach of the New South Wales team for the past five years but is now thought to want out due to personal reasons. Page 80.

Australian long-distance swimmer Susie Maroney suffered a setback last weekend in her preparation for her second Cuba-to-Florida race attempt after she was forced to cut short a 33 kilometre training swim in the Whitsundays Islands when she could not get an adequate protective shark cage supplied in time. Page 78.
